section_id: ## 3. IG Edges: Asymmetric Selection Coupling with Spinor Data

hints.label: def-ig-edges
hints.title: Information Graph (IG) Edges (Directed)
hints.content:
222: :label: def-ig-edges
223: 
224: The **IG edge set** encodes **directed, asymmetric selection coupling** between walkers at the **same timestep**:
225: 
226: $$
227: E_{\text{IG}} := \{(n_{i,t}, n_{j,t}) : i, j \in \{1, \ldots, N\}, \, i \neq j, \, s(n_{i,t}) = 1, \, s(n_{j,t}) = 1\},
228: 
229: $$
230: 
231: where:
232: - Edges are **directed**: $(n_{i,t}, n_{j,t})$ represents the influence of walker $j$ on walker $i$'s cloning decision
233: - Both walkers must be **alive** at timestep $t$
234: - Edges form a **complete directed graph** (tournament) at each timestep among alive walkers
235: - For $k = |\mathcal{A}(t)|$ alive walkers, there are $k(k-1)$ directed IG edges (all ordered pairs)
236: 
237: **Asymmetry of cloning:**
238: 
239: The cloning mechanism is fundamentally **antisymmetric**:
240: - Walker $i$ can clone **to** walker $j$ (overwriting $j$'s state)
241: - Walker $j$ cannot simultaneously clone to walker $i$
242: - The edge $(n_{i,t}, n_{j,t})$ stores the **directed cloning potential** $V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j)$
243: 
244: **Interpretation:** The directed edge $(n_{i,t}, n_{j,t})$ encodes:
245: 1. **Viscous coupling**: Walker $j$'s velocity influences walker $i$ via $\mathbf{F}_{\text{viscous}}$
246: 2. **Cloning potential**: Fitness difference $\Phi_j - \Phi_i$ determines cloning probability
247: 3. **Companion selection**: Algorithmic distance for virtual reward computation
hints.section: ## 3. IG Edges: Asymmetric Selection Coupling with Spinor Data
hints.raw_directive:
219: ### 3.1. IG Edge Definition
220: 
221: :::{prf:definition} Information Graph (IG) Edges (Directed)
222: :label: def-ig-edges
223: 
224: The **IG edge set** encodes **directed, asymmetric selection coupling** between walkers at the **same timestep**:
225: 
226: $$
227: E_{\text{IG}} := \{(n_{i,t}, n_{j,t}) : i, j \in \{1, \ldots, N\}, \, i \neq j, \, s(n_{i,t}) = 1, \, s(n_{j,t}) = 1\},
228: 
229: $$
230: 
231: where:
232: - Edges are **directed**: $(n_{i,t}, n_{j,t})$ represents the influence of walker $j$ on walker $i$'s cloning decision
233: - Both walkers must be **alive** at timestep $t$
234: - Edges form a **complete directed graph** (tournament) at each timestep among alive walkers
235: - For $k = |\mathcal{A}(t)|$ alive walkers, there are $k(k-1)$ directed IG edges (all ordered pairs)
236: 
237: **Asymmetry of cloning:**
238: 
239: The cloning mechanism is fundamentally **antisymmetric**:
240: - Walker $i$ can clone **to** walker $j$ (overwriting $j$'s state)
241: - Walker $j$ cannot simultaneously clone to walker $i$
242: - The edge $(n_{i,t}, n_{j,t})$ stores the **directed cloning potential** $V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j)$
243: 
244: **Interpretation:** The directed edge $(n_{i,t}, n_{j,t})$ encodes:
245: 1. **Viscous coupling**: Walker $j$'s velocity influences walker $i$ via $\mathbf{F}_{\text{viscous}}$
246: 2. **Cloning potential**: Fitness difference $\Phi_j - \Phi_i$ determines cloning probability
247: 3. **Companion selection**: Algorithmic distance for virtual reward computation
248:

hints.label: def-cloning-potential
hints.title: Directed Cloning Potential
hints.content:
255: :label: def-cloning-potential
256: 
257: For a directed IG edge $(n_{i,t}, n_{j,t})$ from $j$ to $i$, define the **antisymmetric cloning potential**:
258: 
259: $$
260: V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j) := \Phi_j - \Phi_i
261: 
262: $$
263: 
264: This potential is **antisymmetric** under particle exchange:
265: 
266: $$
267: V_{\text{clone}}(j \to i) = \Phi_i - \Phi_j = -V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j)
268: 
269: $$
270: 
271: **Physical interpretation:**
272: - $V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j) > 0$: Walker $j$ is **fitter** than $i$ → increases $i$'s desire to clone from $j$
273: - $V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j) < 0$: Walker $j$ is **less fit** than $i$ → decreases $i$'s cloning probability
274: - $V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j) = 0$: Equal fitness → neutral influence
275: 
276: **Connection to fermionic antisymmetry:**
277: 
278: The antisymmetry $V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j) = -V_{\text{clone}}(j \to i)$ is the **key property** for deriving fermionic propagators:
279: - In QFT, fermion exchange introduces a **minus sign** (Pauli exclusion)
hints.section: ## 3. IG Edges: Asymmetric Selection Coupling with Spinor Data
hints.raw_directive:
252: ### 3.2. Antisymmetric Cloning Potential
253: 
254: :::{prf:definition} Directed Cloning Potential
255: :label: def-cloning-potential
256: 
257: For a directed IG edge $(n_{i,t}, n_{j,t})$ from $j$ to $i$, define the **antisymmetric cloning potential**:
258: 
259: $$
260: V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j) := \Phi_j - \Phi_i
261: 
262: $$
263: 
264: This potential is **antisymmetric** under particle exchange:
265: 
266: $$
267: V_{\text{clone}}(j \to i) = \Phi_i - \Phi_j = -V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j)
268: 
269: $$
270: 
271: **Physical interpretation:**
272: - $V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j) > 0$: Walker $j$ is **fitter** than $i$ → increases $i$'s desire to clone from $j$
273: - $V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j) < 0$: Walker $j$ is **less fit** than $i$ → decreases $i$'s cloning probability
274: - $V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j) = 0$: Equal fitness → neutral influence
275: 
276: **Connection to fermionic antisymmetry:**
277: 
278: The antisymmetry $V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j) = -V_{\text{clone}}(j \to i)$ is the **key property** for deriving fermionic propagators:
279: - In QFT, fermion exchange introduces a **minus sign** (Pauli exclusion)
280: - In the Fractal Set, cloning asymmetry introduces a **fitness sign flip**

hints.label: def-ig-edge-attributes
hints.title: IG Edge Spinor Attributes (Directed)
hints.content:
287: :label: def-ig-edge-attributes
288: 
289: Each **directed** IG edge $(n_{i,t}, n_{j,t}) \in E_{\text{IG}}$ (from walker $j$ to walker $i$) contains data from the Adaptive Gas SDE:
290: 
291: **Identity:**
292: - $\text{source\_walker} = j$: Walker ID providing influence (source)
293: - $\text{target\_walker} = i$: Walker ID receiving influence (target)
294: - $\text{timestep} = t$: Shared timestep
295: 
296: **Spatial Spinors:**
297: - $\psi_{x_i} \in \mathbb{C}^{2^{[d/2]}}$: Position spinor of walker $i$ (encoding $x_i$)
298: - $\psi_{x_j} \in \mathbb{C}^{2^{[d/2]}}$: Position spinor of walker $j$ (encoding $x_j$)
299: - $\psi_{\Delta x_{ij}} := \psi_{x_j} \ominus \psi_{x_i} \in \mathbb{C}^{2^{[d/2]}}$: Relative position spinor (encodes $x_j - x_i$)
300: 
301: **Velocity Spinors:**
302: - $\psi_{v_i} \in \mathbb{C}^{2^{[d/2]}}$: Velocity spinor of walker $i$
303: - $\psi_{v_j} \in \mathbb{C}^{2^{[d/2]}}$: Velocity spinor of walker $j$
304: - $\psi_{\Delta v_{ij}} := \psi_{v_j} \ominus \psi_{v_i} \in \mathbb{C}^{2^{[d/2]}}$: Relative velocity spinor (encodes $v_j - v_i$)
305: 
306: **Viscous Coupling Spinor:**
307: - $\psi_{\text{viscous},ij} \in \mathbb{C}^{2^{[d/2]}}$: Viscous force contribution from $j$ to $i$:
308: 
309:   $$
310:   \psi_{\text{viscous},ij} := \text{spinor}\left[\nu K_\rho(x_i, x_j) (v_j - v_i)\right]
311: 
312:   $$
313: 
314:   This is the pairwise contribution to $\mathbf{F}_{\text{viscous}}(x_i, S)$ from walker $j$.
315: 
316: **Localization Kernel Weight (Complex Scalar):**
317: - $K_\rho(x_i, x_j) \in \mathbb{R}_{> 0}$: Localization kernel weight
318: - $w_{ij}(\rho) := \frac{K_\rho(x_i, x_j)}{\sum_{\ell \in A_k} K_\rho(x_i, x_\ell)} \in [0,1]$: Normalized weight for localized moments
319: 
320: **Phase Potential and Complex Amplitude:**
321: - $\theta_{ij} := -\frac{d_{\text{alg}}(i,j)^2}{2 \varepsilon_c^2 \hbar_{\text{eff}}} \in \mathbb{R}$: Phase potential encoding algorithmic distance
322: - $\psi_{ij} := \sqrt{P_{\text{comp}}(i,j)} \cdot \exp(i \theta_{ij}) \in \mathbb{C}$: Complex amplitude for quantum-like coupling
323: 
324: where:
325: - $d_{\text{alg}}(i,j)$: Algorithmic distance (from fitness-weighted genealogy)
326: - $\varepsilon_c$: Cloning interaction range (characteristic length scale)
327: - $\hbar_{\text{eff}}$: Effective Planck constant (fundamental algorithmic quantum)
328: - $P_{\text{comp}}(i,j)$: Companion selection probability
329: 
330: **Derived Scalar Quantities:**
331: - $d_{ij} := \|x_i - x_j\| = |\psi_{\Delta x_{ij}}| \in \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$: Euclidean distance
332: 
333: **Antisymmetric Fitness Potential (KEY SCALAR):**
334: - $V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j) := \Phi_j - \Phi_i \in \mathbb{R}$: **Directed fitness difference** (antisymmetric!)
335: 
336:   This is the **primary edge weight** encoding directed influence. It satisfies:
337: 
338:   $$
339:   V_{\text{clone}}(j \to i) = -V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j)
340: 
341:   $$
342: 
343: **Fitness Scalars (from nodes):**
hints.section: ## 3. IG Edges: Asymmetric Selection Coupling with Spinor Data
hints.raw_directive:
284: ### 3.3. IG Edge Spinor Data Structure
285: 
286: :::{prf:definition} IG Edge Spinor Attributes (Directed)
287: :label: def-ig-edge-attributes
288: 
289: Each **directed** IG edge $(n_{i,t}, n_{j,t}) \in E_{\text{IG}}$ (from walker $j$ to walker $i$) contains data from the Adaptive Gas SDE:
290: 
291: **Identity:**
292: - $\text{source\_walker} = j$: Walker ID providing influence (source)
293: - $\text{target\_walker} = i$: Walker ID receiving influence (target)
294: - $\text{timestep} = t$: Shared timestep
295: 
296: **Spatial Spinors:**
297: - $\psi_{x_i} \in \mathbb{C}^{2^{[d/2]}}$: Position spinor of walker $i$ (encoding $x_i$)
298: - $\psi_{x_j} \in \mathbb{C}^{2^{[d/2]}}$: Position spinor of walker $j$ (encoding $x_j$)
299: - $\psi_{\Delta x_{ij}} := \psi_{x_j} \ominus \psi_{x_i} \in \mathbb{C}^{2^{[d/2]}}$: Relative position spinor (encodes $x_j - x_i$)
300: 
301: **Velocity Spinors:**
302: - $\psi_{v_i} \in \mathbb{C}^{2^{[d/2]}}$: Velocity spinor of walker $i$
303: - $\psi_{v_j} \in \mathbb{C}^{2^{[d/2]}}$: Velocity spinor of walker $j$
304: - $\psi_{\Delta v_{ij}} := \psi_{v_j} \ominus \psi_{v_i} \in \mathbb{C}^{2^{[d/2]}}$: Relative velocity spinor (encodes $v_j - v_i$)
305: 
306: **Viscous Coupling Spinor:**
307: - $\psi_{\text{viscous},ij} \in \mathbb{C}^{2^{[d/2]}}$: Viscous force contribution from $j$ to $i$:
308: 
309:   $$
310:   \psi_{\text{viscous},ij} := \text{spinor}\left[\nu K_\rho(x_i, x_j) (v_j - v_i)\right]
311: 
312:   $$
313: 
314:   This is the pairwise contribution to $\mathbf{F}_{\text{viscous}}(x_i, S)$ from walker $j$.
315: 
316: **Localization Kernel Weight (Complex Scalar):**
317: - $K_\rho(x_i, x_j) \in \mathbb{R}_{> 0}$: Localization kernel weight
318: - $w_{ij}(\rho) := \frac{K_\rho(x_i, x_j)}{\sum_{\ell \in A_k} K_\rho(x_i, x_\ell)} \in [0,1]$: Normalized weight for localized moments
319: 
320: **Phase Potential and Complex Amplitude:**
321: - $\theta_{ij} := -\frac{d_{\text{alg}}(i,j)^2}{2 \varepsilon_c^2 \hbar_{\text{eff}}} \in \mathbb{R}$: Phase potential encoding algorithmic distance
322: - $\psi_{ij} := \sqrt{P_{\text{comp}}(i,j)} \cdot \exp(i \theta_{ij}) \in \mathbb{C}$: Complex amplitude for quantum-like coupling
323: 
324: where:
325: - $d_{\text{alg}}(i,j)$: Algorithmic distance (from fitness-weighted genealogy)
326: - $\varepsilon_c$: Cloning interaction range (characteristic length scale)
327: - $\hbar_{\text{eff}}$: Effective Planck constant (fundamental algorithmic quantum)
328: - $P_{\text{comp}}(i,j)$: Companion selection probability
329: 
330: **Derived Scalar Quantities:**
331: - $d_{ij} := \|x_i - x_j\| = |\psi_{\Delta x_{ij}}| \in \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$: Euclidean distance
332: 
333: **Antisymmetric Fitness Potential (KEY SCALAR):**
334: - $V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j) := \Phi_j - \Phi_i \in \mathbb{R}$: **Directed fitness difference** (antisymmetric!)
335: 
336:   This is the **primary edge weight** encoding directed influence. It satisfies:
337: 
338:   $$
339:   V_{\text{clone}}(j \to i) = -V_{\text{clone}}(i \to j)
340: 
341:   $$
342: 
343: **Fitness Scalars (from nodes):**
344: - $\Phi_i := \Phi(n_{i,t}) \in \mathbb{R}$: Fitness of target walker $i$
